in-person seminar or other discussion format

comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how to better analyze texts, what American Literature entails and what is included under that label.

I grew as both a writer and a thinker, learning more about the history of American lit and closely examining the question of what it means for something to be "American." The readings were also very diverse, allowing us to interrogate a wide range of interesting questions of what falls under this umbrella of "American."
I learned about conceptions of American literature and read some amazing texts all across American history.

I learned not only how to be a better writer and engage with various types of literature, but I learned a lot of history, too. I learned about the diversity of American literature and the various stories that comprise the American voice. I also learned how to discuss these topics with my peers in a sensitive, empathetic, and scholarly way.
Reading and writing about American literature, Literary analysis

This course was one of the most eye-opening courses I've taken at Yale. Professor Hickey is a genius and can make sense of really difficult concepts when we're analyzing literature, and also, there were student-led question-based discussions that really developed interdependent critical thinking. Overall a great course to just learn about the world, injustice, character dynamics, and of course analyzing literature.
Knowledge on the wide breadth of American Literature (Melville, Ocean Vuong, James Baldwin, etc.)
I got to enjoy a lot of literary works which were new to me; I practiced my analytical-essay-writing skills.

I gained a fundamental understanding of American literature, literary analysis, and research writing in ENGL 127. This class really helped me improve my analytical writing abilities, critical thinking, and research capabilities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Hickey is by far the biggest strength. Truly an amazing professor! I loved how she would present the historical/sociocultural background of a work of literature and then we could all discuss it as a class. She's excellent at facilitating conversation and encouraging students to speak up. Also, this class had a real sense of community because of Prof. Hickey, which I was super thankful for during this virtual semester.
Amazing course with an amazing syllabus!

Strengths: ALANNA HICKEY! The kindest, sweetest, most passionate and most intelligent individuals I have ever met! I wish this semester could have been in person so that we could have met her. The environment she created, even though it was all virtual, felt so close knit and supportive. I really felt that by the end of the class I could call many of my peers friends. honestly writing this is making me tear up a little bit because I'm sad I won't be able to take this course next semester.
Weaknesses: I actually can't think of any. this class was BY FAR my favorite that I have taken at Yale.

The strength of this course was the amazing engagement that all of the students had with the course. Even though it was on zoom, I had a great time connecting and discussing topics with Professor Hickey and my classmates.

The course was so engaging, the course material was wonderful (I loved the readings), and the structure of the class was great. It was the perfect balance between positing my own thoughts and growing and learning from others'. I didn't really feel like the course could be improved. It was such a great class, and Professor Hickey was hands down one of the best professors I've ever had at Yale. She handled going virtual so well.

Strengths: PROF. HICKEY!!!!! She brings amazing texts and flare to every class session. There was a diverse mix of authors and I loved the majority of the syllabus (even Melville, whose Bartleby had me preferring not to engage with capitalism :). But the real strength of this class is Hickey, who is very kind, warmhearted and engages with her students extremely well.

Prof. Hickey led really engaging discussions and was always open to our ideas about the literature; while she provided necessary contextual information about the works and authors at the beginning of class, she opened up the discussions from there. She approaches teaching with a lot of compassion.

The reading load was a little uneven at first, but Prof. Hickey responded quickly and evened out the schedule, so it wasn't really an issue.

Strengths -- professor Hickey did a wonderful job and was incredibly accommodating to students given the unprecedented nature of the online format of the class. The readings were also very engaging and carefully chosen to craft an exceptional curriculum that examined both iconic American works like Walt Whitman's Song of Myself and Herman Melville's Bartleby while also incorporating the diverse voices of more modern authors such as Zitkala-Sa and Ocean Vuong. Feedback received on assignments/papers was also always clear, thought-provoking, and helpful in revising different drafts of a work.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think seminar format succeeded for this class-- it facilitated a good level of engagement with me and my classmates.

The check-ins were amazing! Prof. Hickey, thank you so much for incorporating that into class! It was so wonderful to talk about what was going on in our lives and hear how everyone else was doing. It's not a normal semester, and I really appreciate you acknowledging that.
Prof. Hickey offered alternative assignments to two of our essays that were extremely engaging and intellectually challenging without draining us any more than the online semester already had.

succeeded: I love that for many assignments, we were given an "alternative" assignment that was more oriented towards the unusual circumstances of the semester. That was amazing and I really enjoyed it, and it felt very considerate. 

improvements: none

The practices which succeeded were Professor Hickey's creative ways of making assignments that did not involve staring at our screens. For example, for my midterm I exchanged letters with my classmates about Song of Solomon. It took a lot of thought and time, but it was so refreshing and opened my eyes to new ways of analyzing literature.

I'm definitely not a big fan of virtual learning at all, but Professor Hickey did a great job of just easing the stress and confines of those circumstances. The course was facilitated and led by students and there wasn't any pressure to speak on every single topic we talked about.

The daily check-ins at the beginning of the class were a highlight of the course for me. It was nice to know that we had a professor who cared about our wellbeing as students apart from our academic achievements and who would support us through the many challenges we all encountered during this difficult semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course.

Yes, yes, yes! It's worth it to take it just to have Prof. Hickey as your professor. She's amazing! And the works you engage with are so interesting and informative. Even if you don't like some of the reading (I still don't like Whitman haha!), you get so much out of working with the texts.
Yes yes yes! Could not recommend any less.

ABSOLUTELY, especially with Prof. Hickey. It is a great introduction to American Literature and the English department. You will learn so much, become a better writer, and hopefully even make friends! Prof. Hickey is supportive and passionate-- you couldn't ask for a better professor.
Yes! This class is so fun. Professor Hickey creates such a warm class environment and does a great job at teaching her amazing syllabus. I really enjoyed this class.

Yes absolutely. Like I said, Professor Hickey will just blow you out of the water. She's an incredible professor. The readings of this class are already fantastic, but she has such a great grip on analyzing them that you just learn so much.
Yes of course!!! If you get Engl 127 with Prof. Hickey TAKE IT
I would absolutely recommend this course for anyone who enjoys literature.
Absolutely. See "strengths" above.
